Award.AwardTitle: Lower Curvature Bounds, Symmetries, and Topology
Award.AbstractNarration:
Award: DMS 1611780, Principal Investigator: Catherine E. Searle

Global Riemannian geometry generalizes the classical Euclidean, Spherical and Hyperbolic geometries to a wide variety of geometric spaces in which the distance between points is described by minimizing the lengths of curves that join those points. Curvature or bending properties of Riemannian spaces generalize the visual sense we have that a sphere is round (positively curved, with the sense that curvature is related to the diameter of the sphere, and that a sphere of smaller diameter is more greatly curved than a sphere of large diameter) or Euclidean space is flat (of zero curvature). Differential geometers construct local ways to measure the curvature or bending properties of a geometry, and a major goal is to relate these local aspects of a Riemannian space to global properties that are much more flexible and are described as topology. For example, if a space has the property that around every point there is a neighborhood that is metrically identical to the arctic region of a sphere of radius 1, must the entire space turn out to be identical to that sphere? (The answer is no, but not by much.) What happens if those neighborhoods are merely close in metric properties to that arctic region - does changing from constant curvature to allowing small variations change that answer? Several versions of the notion of curvature are studied, summarizing local geometry in greater or lesser levels of detail, and manifolds with curvature bounds have been studied intensively since the inception of global Riemannian geometry. The projects supported by this grant will study symmetries of Riemannian manifolds and of some related spaces in the presence of lower bounds on curvature.

This research program concerns both sectional curvature and Ricci curvature lower bounds and their corresponding generalizations to Alexandrov spaces, with an eye to gaining a deeper understanding of this largely unknown class of spaces. Basic problems in this agenda concern the following areas: (1) symmetries and topology of positively and non-negatively curved Riemannian manifolds and Alexandrov spaces and (2) symmetries and topology of Riemannian manifolds of positive Ricci curvature and almost non-negative sectional curvature. Classification problems in these regimes are both difficult and intriguing, and touch on several mathematical specialties that are neighbors of differential geometry, including Lie groups and their actions on manifolds, as well as algebraic topology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Global Riemannian Geometry generalizes the classical  Euclidean, Spherical and Hyberbolic geometries. One of the major challenges is to understand how local invariants such as curvature relate to global topological invariants such as fundamental group. 

Manifolds with curvature bounds have been studied intensively since the conception of global Riemannian geometry. One approach to studying manifolds with lower curvature bounds has been to introduce symmetries. This approach can also be used to study the more general class of spaces known as Alexandrov spaces.

In this project I  analyzed and studied symmetries of both Riemannian manifolds with lower curvature bounds and Alexandrov spaces, considering both sectional curvature and Ricci curvature lower bounds and their corresponding generalizations to Alexandrov spaces, with an eye to gaining a deeper understanding of  this largely unknown class of spaces. 

 Intellectual Merit:

I highlight two results from this project.

The first is the classification of closed, simply-connected manifolds of non-negative curvature admitting an isotropy maximal torus action. Christine Escher, and I showed that these manifolds are products of spheres or the quotients of products spheres by a free torus action. This classification has consequences for the maximal symmetry rank conjecture for non-negatively curved manifolds and led to a classification of closed, simply-connected manifolds of non-negative curvature admitting a torus action of maximal symmetry rank in dimensions less than or equal to 9.

The second result is the classification of closed, simply-connected 4-manifolds of almost non-negative curvature admitting an isometric circle action. Working with John Harvey, we showed that such manifolds are exactly those manifolds that admit a metric of non-negative curvature and an isometric circle action. This result gives further support for Grove's extension of the Bott conjecture which states that closed, simply-connected manifolds of almost non-negative curvature are rationally elliptic.

Broader Impacts:

Under my supervision,  Mia Harper, Sara Muzzy, and Austin Bosgraaf, all first generation students, wrote their masters theses while at Wichta State University. I also co-supervised, with Christine Escher, the PhD thesis of Zheting Dong at Oregon State University.

I co-organized a number of seminars and conferences, including two AMS special sessions, the Midwest Geometry Conference, the Women in Geometry 2 workshop, and the Symmetries in Geometry on the Southern Great Plains conference. I also participated in a number of outreach activities, including speaking at the Wichita State University Math Circle, participating in the Fairmount Summer Community Outreach program, acting as faculty advisor to the newly created WSU math club, and mentoring sutdents both at WSU and other undergraduate institutions via the Math Alliance F-GAP program.
